footnotes = }} '''Robert Sherman''' "'''Bob'''" '''Halperin''' (January 26, 1908 – May 8, 1985), nicknamed "'''Buck'''", was an American competitive [[Star (sailboat)|Star class]] sailor, and [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] [[bronze medalist]] and [[Pan American Games]] [[gold medalist]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dAq4TGQsWwwC&pg=PA121 |title=Day by day in Jewish sports history |publisher=KTAV Publishing House, Inc. |year=2008 |author=Bob Wechsler |ISBN=0-88125-969-1 |accessdate=July 11, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1985-05-09/news/8501290068_1_mr-halperin-palm-springs-landing |title=Robert Halperin, 77, War Hero, Executive |work=Chicago Tribune |date=May 9, 1985 |author=Kenan Heise |accessdate=July 11, 2011}} He was also a college and [[NFL]] [[American football|football]] quarterback, one of [[Chicago]]'s most-decorated World War II heroes, co-founder of [[Lands' End]], and chairman of [[Commercial Light Company]]. ==Early and personal life== Halperin was born in Chicago, Illinois, and was Jewish.{{cite web |url=http://www.jewishsports.net/medalists.htm |author= George Eisen |title=Jewish Olympic Medalists |publisher=International Jewish Sports Hall of Fame |date= |accessdate=July 11, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ha/bob-halperin-1.html |title=Bob Halperin Biography and Olympic Results |publisher=Sports-reference.com |date= |accessdate=July 11, 2011}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PrEuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HWEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2768,1596842&dq=bob-halperin+jewish&hl=en |title=Jewish Youth Led Assault Boats on D-Day |work=The Canadian Jewish Chronicle |date=June 16, 1944 |accessdate=July 11, 2011}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xcfef_d2es4C&pg=PA191&dq=%22robert+halperin%22+jewish&hl=en&ei=dUwbTsPaD8GRgQfPuPgF&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=The Big Book of Jewish Sports Heroes: An Illustrated Compendium of Sports History and The 150 Greatest Jewish Sports Stars |publisher=SP Books |year=2007 |author=Peter S. Horvitz |ISBN=1-56171-907-2 |accessdate=July 11, 2011}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O73WAAAAMAAJ&q=%22robert+halperin%22+jewish&dq=%22robert+halperin%22+jewish&hl=en&ei=dUwbTsPaD8GRgQfPuPgF&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAw |title=Jews and American Popular Culture: Sports, leisure, and lifestyle |publisher=Praeger Publishers |year=2007 |author=Paul Buhle |ISBN=0-275-98796-5 |accessdate=July 11, 2011}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rFo7AQAAIAAJ&q=%22robert+halperin%22+jewish&dq=%22robert+halperin%22+jewish&hl=en&ei=dUwbTsPaD8GRgQfPuPgF&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CD0Q6AEwBA |title=Jews and the Olympic Games; sport: a springboard for minorities |publisher=Vallentine Mitchell |year=2004 |author=Paul Yogi Mayer |ISBN=0-85303-516-4 |accessdate=July 11, 2011}} His father, Aaron, immigrated to the United States from [[Kiev]] in the 1890s, and died in 1964.{{cite news |url=http://2fpqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/639987532.html?dids=639987532:639987532&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Oct+17%2C+1964&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Obituary+4+--+No+Title&pqatl=google |title=Obituary |work=Chicago Tribune |date=October 17, 1964 |accessdate=July 13, 2011}} His mother, Julia, died in 1976.{{cite news |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/613167832.html?dids=613167832:613167832&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Apr+29%2C+1976&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Obituary+2+--+No+Title&pqatl=google |title=Obituary |work=Chicago Tribune |date=April 29, 1976 |accessdate=July 13, 2011}} He and his wife Margaret Stralka raised three sons, Thomas, Patrick and Daniel, the latter was Robert's biological son. He lived in the [[Near North Side, Chicago|Near North Side]] of Chicago, and [[Palm Springs, California]]. ==Football career== In high school, he played football for [[Oak Park and River Forest High School|Oak Park High School]]. He was also captain of the football team.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rYtFAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8bwMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4631,4237955&dq=buck-halperin&hl=en |title=Numbers Issued to Badger 11 |work=The Telegraph-Herald and Times-Journal |date=September 23, 1929 |accessdate=July 12, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/451394412.html?dids=451394412:451394412&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Sep+05%2C+1926&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=OAK+PARK+FRAT+BOYS+WIN+BACK+PLACES+IN+SCHOOL&pqatl=google |title=Oak Park Frat Boys Win Back Places in School |work=Chicago Tribune |date=September 5, 1926 |accessdate=July 13, 2011}}{{cite news |author=Monday, May 17, 1926 |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,769349,00.html |title=Education: Brothers under the Rose |work=TIME |date=May 17, 1926 |accessdate=July 13, 2011}} In college, Halperin first played football for [[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]], at quarterback under Coach [[Knute Rockne]]. He then played football for the [[University of Wisconsin]], from which he graduated in 1932.{{cite web |url=http://www.jewsinsports.org/Olympics.asp?sport=olympics&ID=250 |title=Halperin, Robert "Buck" |publisher=Jews in Sports |date= |accessdate=July 12, 2011}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MnnfAAAAMAAJ&q=%22buck+halperin%22&dq=%22buck+halperin%22&hl=en&ei=aJAbTqyXAaqt0AHhm9XpBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAg |title=Scouts and Raiders: the Navy's first special warfare commandos |publisher=Praeger |year=1993 |author=John B. Dwyer |ISBN=0-275-94409-3 |accessdate=July 12, 2011}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wteXboW3XTIC&pg=PA265&lpg=PA265&dq=%22robert+halperin%22+%22brooklyn+dodgers%22&source=bl&ots=kalgnlR-vP&sig=c0lUyMwzl7VyJSa-NGvAJv1vZdc&hl=en&ei=sk4bTuiUJ4e40AH3prCWBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAg#v=snippet&q=%22halperin%22%20&f=false |title=Tales of Valor |publisher=Xlibris Corporation |year=2004 |author=Howard J. Leavitt |ISBN=1-4134-1131-2 |accessdate=July 13, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=CSTB&p_theme=cstb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB421D59DF0A89D&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Notre Dame Class Acts |work=Chicago Sun-Times |date=August 22, 1994 |accessdate=July 13, 2011}} After graduating college, in 1932 he played professional football at quarterback for the [[Brooklyn Dodgers (NFL)|Brooklyn Dodgers]] team in the [[National Football League]], under coach [[Benny Friedman]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PPrSAAAAMAAJ&q=%22bob+halperin%22+jewish&dq=%22bob+halperin%22+jewish&hl=en&ei=jEobTqCEGu630AHEqcmWBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAQ |title=Jews fight too! |publisher=Jordon Publishing Co. |year=1945 |author=Mac Davis |accessdate=July 11, 2011}} He later coached football at [[St. Patrick High School (Chicago)|St. Patrick High School]].{{cite news |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/388349111.html?dids=388349111:388349111&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Nov+02%2C+1932&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=BROOKLYN+GRIDDERS+SIGN+TWO+PLAYERS&pqatl=google |title=Brooklyn Gridders Sign Two Players |work=Los Angeles Times |date=November 2, 1932 |accessdate=July 12, 2011}} ==Navy career== [[File:Navycross.jpg|thumb |125px |[[Navy Cross (United States)|Navy Cross]]]] Halperin was one of Chicago`s most decorated sailors in World War II. He joined the [[U.S. Navy]] on March 19, 1942, when World War II started, ultimately rising to the level of [[Lieutenant Commander]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WfVKAAAAYAAJ&q=%22bob+halperin%22+jewish&dq=%22bob+halperin%22+jewish&hl=en&ei=jEobTqCEGu630AHEqcmWBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA |title=The Jewish Veteran |publisher=Jewish War Veterans of the USA |year=1944 |author=Jewish War Veterans of the United States of America |accessdate=July 11, 2011}} He trained first under boxer [[Gene Tunney]], and then in a top-secret program in 1942 at [[Naval Amphibious Base Little Creek]] in Little Creek, Virginia, along with fellow NFL football players [[Phil Bucklew]] and [[John Tripson]] and seven others who made up the first class of what became known as the [[Scouts and Raiders|Navy Scouts & Raiders]], a predecessor of the [[Navy Seals]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z0ifnvAC5IoC&pg=PA121&dq=%22robert+halperin%22+navy&hl=en&ei=fjgeTvybN4b30gHjpZyaAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22robert%20halperin%22%20navy&f=false |title=The frogmen of World War II: an oral history of the U.S. Navy's underwater demolition teams |ISBN=0-7434-8216-6 |publisher=Simon and Schuster |year=2004 |author=Chet Cunningham |accessdate=July 24, 2011}}{{cite book |url=https://archive.org/stream/byseaandbyland017611mbp/byseaandbyland017611mbp_djvu.txt |title=By Sea And By Land; The Story of Our Amphibious Forces |publisher=Whittlesey House, a division of the McGraw-Hill Book Company, Inc. |year=1944 |author=Lieut. Earl Burton |accessdate=July 24, 2011}} The three former NFL players were among 1,000 NFL players who served in the military for the U.S. during World War II.{{cite web |url=http://www.profootballhof.com/history/general/war/worldwar2/honor_roll.aspx?print=y |title=Football and America: World War II |publisher=Profootballhof.com |date= |accessdate=July 24, 2011}} The job of the trainees was to locate designated landing beaches at night for amphibious landings, note any obstacles, and guide the attacking troops and their landing craft. War correspondent William H. Stoneman wrote of Halperin: "His job is to mark beaches for the assault, infantry, a daring, intricate job, calling for as much brain as courage, and barrels of both." He was in charge of 14 scout boats, the first to arrive in France in the [[Normandy landings]]. Halperin saw action in [[Allied invasion of Sicily|Sicily]], [[Italian Campaign (World War II)|Italy]], [[European Theatre of World War II|Europe]] (including during [[D-Day]]), [[North African Campaign|North Africa]], and the [[Pacific War|Pacific]]. He was decorated for gallantry with the [[Navy Cross (United States)|Navy Cross]], the [[Silver Star]], two [[Bronze Stars]], and a [[Presidential Unit Citation (United States)|Presidential Citation]], as well as the highest honor of the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Nationalist Chinese government]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nmajmh.org/exhibitions/catalog-hallOfHeroes/cat43.php |title=Hall of Heroes: American Jewish Medal Recipients |publisher=Nmajmh.org |date= |accessdate=July 11, 2011}} In the North Africa invasion in November 1942, he sailed his scout ship from seven miles off-shore in complete darkness to the shore of [[French Morocco]], located and marked landing beaches with landing signals, guided assault troops to their targets while being [[strafe]]d by enemy planes, and became the first American in the invasion to capture two of the enemy when he personally captured two enemy officers.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9qciAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Ya8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=2722,5157731&dq=robert-halperin+brooklyn-dodgers&hl=en |title=Pro Football Stars Run Interference for Allied Troops |work=The Daily Times |date=June 17, 1944 |accessdate=July 13, 2011}}{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vwwEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT72&dq=%22bob+halperin%22+navy&hl=en&ei=UZwbToi1H6rZ0QH1y4XKBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDkQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22bob%20halperin%22%20navy&f=false |title=Mills Industries at War |publisher=Billboard |date=October 30, 1943 |author=James T. Mangan |accessdate=July 24, 2011}} In recognition of his efforts, including his extraordinary heroism, skill, courage, and fearless devotion to duty, he received a presidential citation and the Navy Cross. He was promoted to Lieutenant Commander for his actions in the assault on [[Scoglitti]] on the southeastern coast of Sicily in July–August 1943.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3tdCAAAAIAAJ&q=%22robert+halperin%22+%22brooklyn+dodgers%22&dq=%22robert+halperin%22+%22brooklyn+dodgers%22&hl=en&ei=9x4dTvu8MI6dgQe77tnmCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CD8Q6AEwAw |title=To all hands: an amphibious adventure |publisher=Whittlesey House |year=1943 |author=John Mason Brown |accessdate=July 13, 2011}} He received a Presidential Citation for his work at [[Gela]], in Sicily. During the [[Normandy Invasion]] of the [[Cherbourg peninsula|Cherbourg Peninsula]], in June 1944 he guided the first two waves of [[assault troops]] to the assault beaches, against entrenched strong opposition, and saved two men from drowning. The ''Chicago Tribune'' notes he was "one of the first Americans to go ashore in France—perhaps, the first—on D-Day." For his exceptionally meritorious performance of duty, and his "cool judgment and unusual ability", he was awarded a Bronze Star. [[File:Order of the Cloud and Banner star.jpg|thumb |125px |[[Order of the Cloud and Banner|Cloud Banner]]]] He was Commanding Officer of U.S. Naval Unit Six, from December 1944 to September 1945, in secret guerrilla action against the Japanese behind enemy lines in [[Fukien Province]], China. During that time, his team of Americans trained 2,500 Chinese guerrillas to fight the Japanese, planned and executed operations resulting in the killing of 1,300 enemy troops and the destruction of tons of their shipping, and he assisted in the rescue of 16 U.S. fliers. While out-numbered and facing an enemy with superior equipment, he attacked the enemy with ambushes and in pitched battles, significantly depleting their forces. He was located in [[Chungking]], [[Kunming]], Camp 6, Hwaan, [[Changchow]], Kulangsu, and [[Shanghai]].{{cite news |url=http://www.saconavy.com/enlisted_men_w_dates_camps.htm |title=Saco Men |publisher=Saconavy.com |date= |accessdate=July 24, 2011}} He was granted a [[Gold Medal]] in lieu of a second Bronze Medal, for "distinguishing himself by exceptionally meritorious conduct. For distinguishing himself "by gallantry and intrepidity", he was awarded a Silver Star. In addition, the Nationalist Chinese government awarded him the Yun Hui "[[Order of the Cloud and Banner|Cloud Banner]]", its highest honor. ==Sailing career== Halperin, sailed for the [[Chicago Yacht Club]] and the Southern Lake Michigan Fleet. He won the North American Star Championship in 1959. He won a [[bronze medal]] for the United States in the [[Star (sailboat)|Star class]] (mixed two-person [[keelboat]]) at the [[1960 Summer Olympics]] in the [[Bay of Naples]] in Italy, at the age of 52, together with [[William Parks (sailor)|William Parks]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ha/bob-halperin-1.html |title=Bob Halperin |publisher=Sports-reference.com |accessdate=March 5, 2011}}{{cite web |url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0015_0_15093.html |title=Olympic Games |publisher=Jewish Virtual Library |date= |accessdate=July 11, 2011}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AgmDAAAAMAAJ&q=%22robert+sherman+halperin%22&dq=%22robert+sherman+halperin%22&hl=en&ei=gosbTtqLJpSq0AHQ1oTyBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAw |title=Encyclopedia of Jews in Sports |publisher=Bloch Pub. Co. |year=1965 |author1=Bernard Postal |author2=Jesse Silver |author3=Roy Silver |accessdate=July 12, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.sailing.org/olympics/1960-olympic-games.php?rgtaid=10782&evntid=20806&nocache=1 |title=ISAF: Olympic Games: Past Editions: 1960 Rome Olympic Sailing Competition |publisher=Sailing.org |date=March 16, 2010 |accessdate=July 12, 2011}} Their yacht was the ''Shrew II''. In 1963, he won a [[gold medal]] along with [[Richard Stearns (sailor)|Richard Stearns]] at the [[1963 Pan American Games|Pan American Games]] in [[Sao Paulo, Brazil]], sailing the ''Ninotchka''.{{cite news |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/633488992.html?dids=633488992:633488992&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=May+05%2C+1963&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Following+the+Fleet&pqatl=google |title=Following the Fleet |work=Chicago Tribune |date=May 5, 1963 |accessdate=July 12, 2011}} At the World Championships, the names of the crew whose yacht has the best total score are engraved on the Buck Halperin Trophy, named after him. ===Hall of Fame=== Halperin was inducted as a member of the [[Chicagoland Sports Hall of Fame]] in 1989.{{cite web |url=http://www.clshf.com/hall_of_fame.htm |title=Chicagoland Sports Hall of Famers |publisher=Clshf.com |date= |accessdate=July 12, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://docs.newsbank.com/g/GooglePM/CSTB/lib00225,0EB36E67C0B437CC.html |title=Chicago Sports Hall of Fame Members |work=Chicago Sun-Times |date=July 3, 1989 |accessdate=July 13, 2011}} ==Business career== In business, Halperin became an executive of and rose to become Chairman of Commercial Light Company, a large electrical contractor and engineering business which his father had founded in 1915 and for which did electrical work in many Chicago buildings. He became the company's President in 1959, and Chairman in the 1960s. The company was involved in projects at, the [[John Hancock Center]], [[O'Hare International Airport]], and [[Wrigley Field]].{{cite web |url=http://www.electri.org/newsletter/report.cfm?articleID=685 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005223608/http://www.electri.org/newsletter/report.cfm?articleID=685 |archivedate=October 5, 2011 |title=Electri International: The Foundation for Electrical Construction Inc |publisher=Electri.org |date= |accessdate=March 25, 2016}} He also started the company [[Lands' End]], in the Spring of 1963, with fellow sailor [[Richard Stearns (sailor)|Richard Stearns]], Halperin's close friend [[Gary Comer]], and two of Stearns' employees.{{cite web |url=http://www.anbhf.org/laureates/gcomer.htm |title=American National Business Hall of Fame |publisher=Anbhf.org |date= |accessdate=July 12, 2011}} ==Death== Halperin died May 8, 1985, in [[Palm Springs, California]], at the age of 77.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QNUuAQAAIAAJ&q=%22buck+halperin%22&dq=%22buck+halperin%22&hl=en&ei=aJAbTqyXAaqt0AHhm9XpBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAQ |title=Encyclopaedia Judaica year book |publisher=Encyclopaedia Judaica |year=1986 |accessdate=July 12, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/25008845.html?dids=25008845:25008845&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+12%2C+1985&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=Edmond+O%27Brien%2C+69%2C+who+won+an+Oscar+for+best+supporting&pqatl=google |title=Edmond O'Brien, 69, who won an Oscar for best supporting |work=Chicago Tribune |date=May 12, 1985 |accessdate=July 12, 2011}} His body is at rest at Arlington National Cemetery with his wife. ==See also== * [[List of Jews in sports#Sailing|List of select Jews in sailing]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0275944093 ''Scouts and Raiders: the Navy's first special warfare commandos''], John B.
